msgSnippet: In Test Mentor (a commercial component testing tool) we supply two mechanisms for arbitrary object validation beyond the normal JUnit-like assertion methods:

In Test Mentor (a commercial component testing tool) we supply two
mechanisms for arbitrary object validation beyond the normal JUnit-like
assertion methods:

1) Provide an extendable hierarchy of reusable test components that
represent specific object comparison strategies. For example, the very
simplest comparison uses object1.equals(object2). More complex strategies
might intelligently validate according to various constraints, perform
conversions first such as folding Strings to upper case or comparing the
toString() form of objects.

2) Define reusable test components or methods that represent strategies for
recursively traversing and extracting object states. These can be applied to
objects under test to extract just those states (instance variables) within
an object or cluster of objects that are of interest in a particular
comparison, and compare them to gold standard versions of those objects.

So the idea behind the above is to make the notion of validation an easily
documented, reusable, sharable, extendable component. Although this is
provided as part of Test Mentor's execution framework and automated test
generation, there's no reason these principles couldn't be applied to any
JUnit test. This validation scheme has been written up and presented as a
general unit testing practice at a number of conferences last year, such as
JavaOne so its fairly generic.

In the case of testing Enumeration you might use #1 above to traverse the
enumerated objects, possibly using #2 to validate that they contain the
expected values.
